abstracts.cdata!:
Audit results were mixed, for although
            the project outcome is rated satisfactory, its
            sustainability is uncertain, given the weak economic, and
            financial position of Belarus. In addition, despite
            substantial institutional development, and satisfactory
            performance by the Borrower, the Bank performance is rated
            as marginally satisfactory, because supervision reporting
            was incomplete, and little was done to support follow-up
            funding generation. This is therefore the main lesson drawn
            from this project. During the early stages of the pilot
            phase of the Global Environment Facility (GEF), it was
            implicitly assumed that environmental follow-up funding,
            would supersede the initial GEF input to support maintenance
            operations. However, this assumption proved incorrect,
            therefore, after ten years of experience, it is now
            suggested that GEF should review the possibility to ensure
            long-term support to protect resources of high global
            biodiversity value, considering a broader view of
            biodiversity, and conservation issues. A more general review
            on how to ensure sustainability of globally valuable
            bio-resources, should be raised at the tenth anniversary of
            the Rio Conference.

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            rated as satisfactory. The key lessons learned are: a) The
            social assessment component of the management plan conducted
            in the last year of the project revealed that public
            awareness of the project objectives and activities was weak.
            Local residents valued the park's conservation
            objectives and would be more supportive of the national park
            if they received some of the benefits. As a result, the
            national park is improving its communication with local
            communities. Participation of local communities would have
            been more successful if the social assessment had been
            conducted earlier in the project. b) The project was
            strongly oriented to achieving results, especially in
            technical subjects. The project design could have been
            improved by identifying discrete results to be achieved at
            different stages of the project, and used as measures of
            success. c) Professional development and training activities
            were an important ingredient of the project's success.
            d) Early in the project, a needs assessment of the Project
            Managing Unit could have identified the need for training in
            the office management and business skills needed to
            implement the project. This could have reduced the initial
            delays in implementation and given greater time to the
            substantive work to be done.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Biodiversity Protection Project will
            initiate programs to conserve the biodiversity of key
            endangered forests and to link these efforts to ongoing
            Global Environmental Facility (GEF) supported work in the
            abutting Bialowieza Primeval Forest (BPF) in Poland. It will
            provide institutional support to the Council of Ministers,
            the National Park, and the Committee of Ecology, to
            undertake biodiversity conservation management activities.
            The GEF operation will support Belarus' effort to
            protect its forest ecosystems. Project investments include:
            (i) institutional support to the Belovezhskaya National
            Park, Council of Ministers and the Committee of Ecology to
            enable them to carry out their biodiversity conservation
            management activities; and (ii) investment in programs to
            preserve endangered forest ecosystems for biodiversity
            conservation through provision of funding for pilot
            investments, land planning (GIS) equipment, air and soil
            monitoring equipment (fixed and mobile), protected area
            planning, financial support for a program for supporting
            transition to ecological agriculture for farms operating
            within the BPF, and professional development, training and
            consulting services.
